title: Factoring Polynomials
description: Factoring a polynomial means expressing it as a product of simpler polynomials (its factors). It is the reverse process of expanding or multiplying polynomials. Factoring is a crucial skill for solving polynomial equations, simplifying rational expressions, and understanding the behavior of polynomial functions (e.g., finding roots/x-intercepts).
key_ideas: Factor: A polynomial that divides another polynomial evenly (with no remainder).
Prime Polynomial: A polynomial that cannot be factored into polynomials of lower degree with integer coefficients (analogous to prime numbers).
Greatest Common Factor (GCF): The largest monomial that is a factor of each term of the polynomial. Always try to factor out the GCF first.

Zero Product Property: If the product of two or more factors is zero, then at least one of the factors must be zero. This is used when solving factored polynomial equations (e.g., if (x-a)(x-b)=0, then x-a=0 or x-b=0).

common_factoring_techniques.name: Greatest Common Factor (GCF)
common_factoring_techniques.description: Find the GCF of all terms and factor it out.

common_factoring_techniques.name: Factoring Trinomials (ax² + bx + c, where a=1)
common_factoring_techniques.description: Find two numbers that multiply to 'c' and add up to 'b'. If x² + bx + c, factors are (x+p)(x+q) where p*q=c and p+q=b.
common_factoring_techniques.solution: Numbers that multiply to 12 and add to 7 are 3 and 4. Factored form: (x + 3)(x + 4).

common_factoring_techniques.name: Factoring Trinomials (ax² + bx + c, where a≠1)
common_factoring_techniques.description: Methods include the 'ac method' (or grouping) or trial and error. For ac method: find two numbers that multiply to a*c and add to b. Rewrite the middle term using these numbers and factor by grouping.
common_factoring_techniques.solution: a*c = 2*3 = 6. Numbers that multiply to 6 and add to 7 are 1 and 6. Rewrite: 2x² + x + 6x + 3. Group: x(2x + 1) + 3(2x + 1). Factored form: (2x + 1)(x + 3).

common_factoring_techniques.name: Sum of Cubes
common_factoring_techniques.description: Formula: a³ + b³ = (a + b)(a² - ab + b²).

common_factoring_techniques.name: Difference of Cubes
common_factoring_techniques.description: Formula: a³ - b³ = (a - b)(a² + ab + b²).

common_factoring_techniques.name: Factoring by Grouping (for four-term polynomials)
common_factoring_techniques.description: Group terms in pairs, factor out GCF from each pair, then factor out the common binomial factor.
common_factoring_techniques.solution: Group: (x³ - 2x²) + (5x - 10). Factor GCFs: x²(x - 2) + 5(x - 2). Factored form: (x - 2)(x² + 5).

solution_steps: Then, factor the trinomial x² + 5x + 6. Find two numbers that multiply to 6 and add to 5 (which are 2 and 3). So, x² + 5x + 6 = (x + 2)(x + 3).
Apply a² - b² = (a - b)(a + b) with a = 2y² and b = 9z.

common_misconceptions: Forgetting to factor out the GCF first.
Sign errors, especially when factoring trinomials or using sum/difference of cubes.
Stopping too early (not factoring completely, e.g., leaving a difference of squares unfactored).
Incorrectly applying the formulas for sum/difference of cubes or squares.
Assuming all trinomials can be factored over integers (some are prime).
real_world_applications: Solving quadratic and higher-degree polynomial equations, which model trajectories, optimization problems, etc.
Simplifying expressions in engineering and physics.
Finding dimensions of shapes given area or volume expressions.
prerequisites: Understanding of polynomial expressions and terms
